My grandmother, rather dryly I might add, had the following grain of wisdom when my father and some of his brothers visited her a few months ago, complaining about the current state of things (I will paraphrase, first and foremost because she isn’t, nor can she speak, English): “It’s been but a few months. You have your health, you have food on your tables, and most of you even have your jobs. The war lasted for five years.” Those were five years where young men were sent to the fronts to die (or the back to starve in trenches). Several years of food shortages, of enemies infiltrating the homeland, of prisoners of war, of having to hide fugitives and bury your radio because it was the only means of information from abroad. No netflix, no internet, our royal family had fled the country, our government was but a puppet ran by a traitor. Our youths ran around in the forests dying for a fatherland that may be eternally lost. If you want to see bad, come back at me in 2025 and tell me it lasted that long. Sure, we don’t know how long this one will last, but I know we aren’t currently eating the bark off trees, making flour from nuts because there’s hardly anything to go around in the harsher winter months. It’s bad, yes. It can get worse, yes. But these are yet to be the worst times humanity has faced. Even the Second World war wasn’t the worst (but very bad in its own right). And we’re not even a year in - yet the world of scientists is more or less collectively working towards a vaccine and other alternative treatments, not due in 2025, but perhaps as soon as next year. Oh, will we reel from the impact of 2020 for years to come, mentally, physically, financially. But the end times? We feel it because we’ve been connected so tightly as a world as of late. We’ve been more isolated, in more dire straits, more ignorant, more aggressive towards our neighbour. These aren’t the end times. These are a silent and boorish time spent speculating far too much whether the end times are upon us.

Warnings of an apocalyptic end of human existence have been around since the 1960’s and the predictions of the Club of Rome. But climate trends of global warming have been more and more clear that we face mass extinction as a result of global warming and the dozens of positive feedback loops we’re seeing. The much-reviled Dr. Guy McPherson has been warning that we’re facing mass extinction by or before 2030, but at this point, 2030 seems optimistic. This year is showing loss of Arctic Ice sufficient to create a ‘blue ocean event’ in the North Pole.This would accelerate warming to the point where we would be unable to grow staple crops such as corn and soybeans. That is not the only threat we’re facing—in 2018 I created a post for Quora on the issues, and it’s here. Our path to the end. The good Dr’s latest peer reviewed paper indicates that COVID19 and the industrial shutdown it started might be enough to lead to mass extinction. https://opastonline.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/will-covid-19-trigger-extinction-of-all-life-on-earth-eesrr-20-.pdf. Those of us who’ve been following the science over the last decade are understanding that time is short.

You could have said the same thing about countless other times in History. And people did. For hundreds of years, people in some sort of crisis (or series of crises) have thought they were living in end times. It’s a very common parochial attitude. In the middle ages, the Plague killed 25 million people, a third of the population of Europe. The Nazis murdered six-million Jews in death camps. I’m betting a lot of them thought they were living in end times, even though capita-E, capital-T End Times is a Christian idea. The citizens of Hiroshima—the ones who survived—probably thought the same thing. As did the citizens of Pompeii. Throughout History, entire populations have been wiped out. There have been invasions, diseases, famines, floods … Sometimes multiple disasters happened at once. In the 20th Century, there was a World War, followed by pandemic, followed by a world-wide economic depression, followed by another World War, which concluded with two cities being destroyed by nuclear weapons. I’m curious how old you are? Did you live through the Cold War like I did? Did you get scared walking to school, worrying a nuke was going to obliterate your town?
